No

### Description

I am facing issue while upgrading angular application from 11 to 12.
I had created demo angular application created using angular cli version 11.2.14.

Issues.Title: fix(core): disallow reactive node creation in consumer context
Issues.Body:
This change introduces a check around reactive node creation. On the high level it disallows creation of the new reactive nodes while executing consumer functions (computed, effects, template dirty-checking).

It might turn out that this check is too restrictive and there are legitimate use-cases for which we would want to allow reactive node creation while executing computed, effect etc. This is why this PR has infrastructure to enable those checks on the per reactive node type.

We do start with the most restrictive version of checks and might gradually releax those checks as we learn more.

Closes #51055
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(core): disallow reactive node creation in consumer context" (#51082)

Issues.Title: feature request: Dynamic Language Translation Support using JSON
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

Currently, Angular does not natively support dynamic language translations using a simple JSON file. To achieve such functionality, developers have to rely on external libraries such as ngx-translate or transloco.

We could argue that if libraries such as transloco and ngx-translate were not necessary, they wouldn't have achieved such success. This is indicative of the need for this feature in the Angular ecosystem.

### Proposed solution

I propose that Angular introduces a feature for dynamic language translations using simple JSON files. This could greatly simplify the process for developers and remove the need for external libraries. The feature should also allow developers to dynamically switch between languages at runtime.

### Alternatives considered

Right now, developers have to use external libraries such as ngx-translate or transloco for this functionality. While these libraries do provide the desired feature, they also introduce additional dependencies to projects and potentially increase the bundle size. Having this feature natively supported by Angular could result in a cleaner and more efficient solution.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feature request: Dynamic Language Translation Support using JSON" (#51065)

Issues.Body:

Yes

### Description

Hello maintainers,

I wanted to bring to your attention that after installing the package, I ran a vulnerability scan with vulert abom on the lock file and discovered that there are over 15 vulnerable dependencies present. As these vulnerabilities can potentially impact the security of the entire project, I am unsure whether to report this under responsible disclosure.

For your reference, here is a link to the report of the package-lock file I scanned: https://vulert.com/vuln-scan/list/a149f3bc-5d76-452e-ae70-68f40d385bfd

I recommend that we take immediate action to address these vulnerabilities and ensure the security of the project. Please let me know if you require any further information.

P.S. this is the lock file i scanned: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/yarn.lock

Thank you.

Issues.Title: Angular Chrome extension gets disconnected from the page after 30sec of inactivity
Issues.Body:
### Is this a bug report or a feature request?

- [X] Bug Report
- [ ] Feature Request

### Please provide the steps to reproduce the issue [Bug Report only]

1. Go to an angular page to use the angular extension on, on Chrome
2. Everything works correctly, hover on the angular tree and see the blue rectangle on the page that highlights the hovered component.
3. Go to a different browser tab (non angular) for 30sec-5min
4. Go back to the angular page and notice that the extension is not working anymore



### Please provide the expected behavior vs the actual behavior you encountered [Bug Report only]

I would expect the extension to still be connected when going back to the page.

### Please provide a screenshot if possible [Bug Report only]

When it works:
![Screenshot 2023-07-17 at 3 57 21 PM](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/6637867/f5ae2f9c-ac61-42e1-9105-842d859ff915)

When it doesn't work:
![Screenshot 2023-07-17 at 4 01 05 PM](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/6637867/d340d4fe-eeb0-492a-8915-7f978817423b)

My guess is that it's related to Chrome killing the service worker after inactivity on the page. See https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1152255#c185
![Screenshot 2023-07-17 at 4 02 05 PM](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/6637867/1894c1fd-cf0c-4d20-ad17-85ce942029a6)

Issues.Title: NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(DynamicTestModule) When Testing with Standalone Component from Library
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

This took a while to narrow down to something I could isolate / re-create.  If I create a standalone component that uses `MatTooltipModule` in a library, and then use that library/component from within a component in an Angular app that doesn't also import `MatTooltipModule`, I get the following `NullInjectorError` when I run unit tests:

```bash
NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(DynamicTestModule)[InjectionToken mat-tooltip-scroll-strategy -> InjectionToken mat-tooltip-scroll-strategy]:
      NullInjectorError: No provider for InjectionToken mat-tooltip-scroll-strategy!
```

`mat-tooltip-scroll-strategy` is an injection token provided by `MatTooltipModule`.  Now, if I build the same component locally in the app, and then use that component in another component, I don't face the issue at all.  It only seems to be when using it from a library.  This also doesn't throw an error at runtime.  It only seems to present itself when testing.  It also works, if I import `MatTooltipModule` again from the component that's using the library-based component.  But I wouldn't expect it to need that, since both are standalone and the component that's using the tooltip imports it.   Not sure if this is relevant, but we use `jest` for testing (with the `jest-preset-angular` library for our config).  

I managed to recreate this in the attached repo, which demonstrates that the locally built component set up works, while the library-built version of the same component doesn't work.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://github.com/michaelfaith/angular-nullinjector-bug

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(DynamicTestModule)[InjectionToken mat-tooltip-scroll-strategy -> InjectionToken mat-tooltip-scroll-strategy]:
      NullInjectorError: No provider for InjectionToken mat-tooltip-scroll-strategy!
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

Node: 16.19.0

OS: win32 x64

Angular: 16.1.5
... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, material, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1601.4

Issues.Title: bug: bundled domino incorrectly returns undefined instead of null for querySelector
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

platform-server

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

The version of Domino bundled with Angular returns `undefined` instead of `null` for `querySelector`. 

This is causing deprecation warnings in Ionic to be incorrectly logged since we expect `querySelector` to return either the Element or `null` [as per the `Element.querySelector` spec](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/element/querySelector).

Ionic issue: https://github.com/ionic-team/ionic-framework/issues/27564
Relevant Ionic code: https://github.com/ionic-team/ionic-framework/blob/721fc6fd9a21c9c03bb21d290e9b1bbd703e43e3/core/src/components/item/item.tsx#L218

----

**Steps to reproduce**

1. Clone the attached repo.
2. Run `npm install`.
3. Run `npm run dev:ssr`.
4. Once the build process is done, access the app in your browser.
5. Observe that `undefined` is logged in the terminal window, but `null` is logged in the browser console.

**Expected Behavior**

I expect `null` to be logged in the terminal window.

**Actual Behavior**

`undefined` was logged in the terminal window.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://github.com/liamdebeasi/ng-ssr-test

Issues.Title: Non-imported standalone components combined with a directive are not reported during compilation
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

In a standalone component, if a component is used but not imported and it also have an imported directive, then the non-imported component will incorrectly:

- not be reported as an error during compilation
- not be reported as an error, nor rendered, during runtime

This create bugs that are hard to detect, especially if the component has a small visual impact and/or you don't visually check every single page.

I expect that a non-imported component always raise errors during compilation, even if they also use directives.

Issues.Title: perf(@angular-devkit/build-angular): use in-memory Sass module resolution cache
Issues.Body:
When using Sass files with module import references in the esbuild-based browser application builder, the module resolution attempts will now be cached in memory. This caching is only local to each entry Sass file currently. However, this may be expanded to encompass all Sass entries within a build in the future. In addition to caching the entire resolution attempt, individual package root resolution is also cached for deep import attempts. This is useful for packages (such as `@material/*`) which deep import to multiple different files in the same package.
With this change combined with the previous lexer change (#25534), package managers (pnpm & Yarn PnP) that require workarounds for functioning resolution will now perform at an equivalent level to other package managers.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "perf(@angular-devkit/build-angular): use in-memory Sass module resolution cache" (#25548)

Issues.Title: Expose internal application builder function
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

The new experimental `buildApplicationInternal` function has a very flexible API. Its support for passing multiple entry points is especially interesting.

Scenario: I'm building a regular old website (MPA), documentation for a component library. There are over 100 components, with each multiple examples that I'd like to run live on the site.
The documentation site is not an Angular SPA, but set up via a "markdown -> static site" generator ([mdbook](https://rust-lang.github.io/mdBook/)).



### Describe the solution you'd like

Expose the internal application builder function, allowing me to build the entire documentation with multiple entry-pointsâ€”each with its own bootstrapâ€”in one go.

```ts
export default createBuilder((input, context) =>
	buildApplicationInternal( // <-- using internal import here
		{
			watch: false,
			progress: false,

			index: false,
			entryPoints: collectEntryPoints(context),

			// more options
		},
		context,
	),
);
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Past solutions for our documentation:

1. Make the documentation a regular angular app. That's how we started out, turns out no one likes writing documentation like this.
2. Copy the aio setup from angular/angular and make our own "markdown pages -> angular app" pipeline. Tried that, but the setup of aio is… not the easiest to understand or maintain if you're not used to it.
3. Use storybook. That's where we're currently at.

Alternatives to exposing the internal application builder function:

4. Build every page into a separate angular app. This makes the build prohibitively slow.
5. Build a single angular app with bootstraps for every documentation page. This would either load all code for all pages for any page, or it would require quite a lot of shenanigans to ensure we don't load all that superfluous javascript over a shabby internal corporate proxy server.
6. Make the multiple entry points available in the existing experimental application builder's schema. For me this solution would work equally well, but I believe the use case (running angular in an MPA) to be so different from what a regular angular app looks like that adding the option will only lead to confusion for developers who just want to build SPAs.
7. Make a separate "MPA application" builder. This puts the onus on the angular team to properly support building Angular MPAs, which I don't expect to align with the goals of the framework.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Expose internal application builder function" (#25556)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): prevent race condition in setting up sass worker pool
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist

Please check to confirm your PR fulfills the following requirements:

<!-- Please check all that apply using "x". -->

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#-commit-message-guidelines
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)

## PR Type

What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:

## What is the current behavior?

Multiple calls to the `SassStylesheetLanguage`'s process function can lead to setting up multiple sass worker pools, only one of which is cleaned up after the esbuild application build.

The result is `ng build` hanging forever waiting for the workers to exit.

Issue Number: N/A

## What is the new behavior?

Prevent the race condition, thus setting up only one worker pool and allowing the process to exit gracefully.

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>evanw/esbuild (esbuild)</summary>

### [`v0.18.13`](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#01813)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/v0.18.12...v0.18.13)

-   Add the `--drop-labels=` option ([#​2398](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/2398))

    If you want to conditionally disable some development-only code and have it not be present in the final production bundle, right now the most straightforward way of doing this is to use the `--define:` flag along with a specially-named global variable. For example, consider the following code:

    ```js
    function main() {
      DEV && doAnExpensiveCheck()
    }
    ```

    You can build this for development and production like this:

    -   Development: `esbuild --define:DEV=true`
    -   Production: `esbuild --define:DEV=false`

    One drawback of this approach is that the resulting code crashes if you don't provide a value for `DEV` with `--define:`. In practice this isn't that big of a problem, and there are also various ways to work around this.

    However, another approach that avoids this drawback is to use JavaScript label statements instead. That's what the `--drop-labels=` flag implements. For example, consider the following code:

    ```js
    function main() {
      DEV: doAnExpensiveCheck()
    }
    ```

    With this release, you can now build this for development and production like this:

    -   Development: `esbuild`
    -   Production: `esbuild --drop-labels=DEV`

    This means that code containing optional development-only checks can now be written such that it's safe to run without any additional configuration. The `--drop-labels=` flag takes comma-separated list of multiple label names to drop.

-   Avoid causing `unhandledRejection` during shutdown ([#​3219](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3219))

    All pending esbuild JavaScript API calls are supposed to fail if esbuild's underlying child process is unexpectedly terminated. This can happen if `SIGINT` is sent to the parent `node` process with Ctrl+C, for example. Previously doing this could also cause an unhandled promise rejection when esbuild attempted to communicate this failure to its own child process that no longer exists. This release now swallows this communication failure, which should prevent this internal unhandled promise rejection. This change means that you can now use esbuild's JavaScript API with a custom `SIGINT` handler that extends the lifetime of the `node` process without esbuild's internals causing an early exit due to an unhandled promise rejection.

-   Update browser compatibility table scripts

    The scripts that esbuild uses to compile its internal browser compatibility table have been overhauled. Briefly:

    -   Converted from JavaScript to TypeScript
    -   Fixed some bugs that resulted in small changes to the table
    -   Added [`caniuse-lite`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/caniuse-lite) and [`@mdn/browser-compat-data`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@​mdn/browser-compat-data) as new data sources (replacing manually-copied information)

    This change means it's now much easier to keep esbuild's internal compatibility tables up to date. You can review the table changes here if you need to debug something about this change:

    -   [JS table changes](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/d259b8fac717ee347c19bd8299f2c26d7c87481a...af1d35c372f78c14f364b63e819fd69548508f55#diff-1649eb68992c79753469f02c097de309adaf7231b45cc816c50bf751af400eb4)
    -   [CSS table changes](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/commit/95feb2e09877597cb929469ce43811bdf11f50c1#diff-4e1c4f269e02c5ea31cbd5138d66751e32cf0e240524ee8a966ac756f0e3c3cd)

</details>

Issues.Title: Usage of Lexer from "@angular/compiler" breaks in production build with v16
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

After upgrading to angular v16 (16.1.3 more specifically) the production build of our app broke (at runtime).
The following error is thrown:

![Bildschirmfoto 2023-07-14 um 10 03 44](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/26869118/0b46e98b-0ec3-4f9b-ade9-637018c84272)

The stack trace was pointing to an import from `@angular/compiler`, where we import the `Lexer` class from.
```
import { Lexer, Token } from '@angular/compiler';
```
I've removed that import temporarily in order to confirm it's the source of the issue and indeed the production build was starting up afterwards.

Note: It was working fine with v15.2.1 as well as when serving it on the dev-server with v16.1.3.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
Uncaught ReferenceError: md is not defined
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 16.1.3
Node: 16.17.1
Package Manager: npm 8.15.0
OS: darwin arm64

Angular: 16.1.3
... animations, cdk, cdk-experimental, cli, common, compiler
... compiler-cli, core, forms, language-service, material
... material-experimental, material-moment-adapter
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                          Version
----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect        0.1601.3
@angular-devkit/build-angular    16.1.3
@angular-devkit/core             16.1.3
@angular-devkit/schematics       16.1.3
@angular-devkit/schematics-cli   16.1.3
@schematics/angular              16.1.3
ng-packagr                       16.1.0
rxjs                             7.8.1
typescript                       4.9.5
```


### Anything else?

Any suggestion how to make this work again?
Why is it working on the dev-server but not in production?

Issues.Title: perf(@angular-devkit/build-angular): inject Sass import/use directive importer information when resolving
Issues.Body: To correctly resolve a package based import reference in a Sass file with pnpm or Yarn PnP, the importer file path must be known. Unfortunately, the Sass compiler does not provided the importer file to import plugins. Previously to workaround this issue, all previously resolved stylesheets were tried as the importer path. This allowed the stylesheets to be resolved but it also could cause a potentially large increase in build time due to the amount of previous stylesheets that would need to be tried. To avoid the performance impact and to also provide more accurate information regarding the importer file, a lexer is now used to extract import information for a stylesheet and inject the importer file path into the specifier. This information is then extracted from the import specifier during the Sass resolution process and allows the underlying package resolution access to a viable location to resolve the package for all package managers. This information is currently limited to specifiers referencing the `@angular` and `@material` package scopes but a comprehensive pre-resolution process may be added in the future.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "perf(@angular-devkit/build-angular): inject Sass import/use directive importer information when resolving" (#25534)

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): configure AOT compiler to skip NgModule scope metadata emit in esbuild
Issues.Body: The esbuild plugin used within the esbuild-based browser application builder will now use the newly introduced internal `supportJitMode` AOT compiler option to disable the emit of NgModule scope metadata functions within the output code. This removes the need to perform an additional transformation of the AOT compiler generated code to immediately remove the metadata. The Angular CLI neither previously nor currently supports hybrid AOT/JIT mode. In the future if this support situation changes, additional behavior may be added control the internal `supportJitMode` option.

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>evanw/esbuild (esbuild)</summary>

### [`v0.18.12`](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#01812)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/v0.18.11...v0.18.12)

-   Fix a panic with `const enum` inside parentheses ([#​3205](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3205))

    This release fixes an edge case where esbuild could potentially panic if a TypeScript `const enum` statement was used inside of a parenthesized expression and was followed by certain other scope-related statements. Here's a minimal example that triggers this edge case:

    ```ts
    (() => {
      const enum E { a };
      () => E.a
    })
    ```

-   Allow a newline in the middle of TypeScript `export type` statement ([#​3225](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3225))

    Previously esbuild incorrectly rejected the following valid TypeScript code:

    ```ts
    export type
    { T };

    export type
    * as foo from 'bar';
    ```

    Code that uses a newline after `export type` is now allowed starting with this release.

-   Fix cross-module inlining of string enums ([#​3210](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3210))

    A refactoring typo in version 0.18.9 accidentally introduced a regression with cross-module inlining of string enums when combined with computed property accesses. This regression has been fixed.

-   Rewrite `.js` to `.ts` inside packages with `exports` ([#​3201](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3201))

    Packages with the `exports` field are supposed to disable node's path resolution behavior that allows you to import a file with a different extension than the one in the source code (for example, importing `foo/bar` to get `foo/bar.js`). And TypeScript has behavior where you can import a non-existent `.js` file and you will get the `.ts` file instead. Previously the presence of the `exports` field caused esbuild to disable all extension manipulation stuff which included both node's implicit file extension searching and TypeScript's file extension swapping. However, TypeScript appears to always apply file extension swapping even in this case. So with this release, esbuild will now rewrite `.js` to `.ts` even inside packages with `exports`.

-   Fix a redirect edge case in esbuild's development server ([#​3208](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3208))

    The development server canonicalizes directory URLs by adding a trailing slash. For example, visiting `/about` redirects to `/about/` if `/about/index.html` would be served. However, if the requested path begins with two slashes, then the redirect incorrectly turned into a protocol-relative URL. For example, visiting `//about` redirected to `//about/` which the browser turns into `http://about/`. This release fixes the bug by canonicalizing the URL path when doing this redirect.

</details>

<details>
<summary>postcss/postcss (postcss)</summary>

### [`v8.4.26`](https://togithub.com/postcss/postcss/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#8426)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/postcss/postcss/compare/8.4.25...8.4.26)

-   Fixed clone methods types.

</details>

Issues.Title: Angular application will not run after upgrade to angular 16.
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

After upgrading my angular 14 application to angular 16, the application will not longer run after building. The application runs in development mode just fine so I did not think it would be a problem after building.  I first tried building and deploying the application via the build server and it will not run. Then I tried building manually from vscode terminal and deploying the app manually and still does not run. The main.js blows up with uncaught reference error where a variable (different variable name each build) is not defined. Of course the code is obfuscated so hard to see what it is trying to do at this point.   See uploaded images..

![Angular 16 error](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/10948856/054d5796-7331-4626-8bea-4be68569e60c)
![Angular 16 error_2](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/10948856/5756cb01-2d0c-4d30-9278-aa77a95001ce)


### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://test.tropicos.org

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
the error is due to an undefined variable in the main.js generated file. here is the command used on the build server to build
node --max_old_space_size=8192 ./node_modules/@angular/cli/bin/ng build --aot=true --base-href="/" --configuration=production --output-path="$(Build.BinariesDirectory)\dist

for my manual test I used 
ng build --aot=true --base-href="/" --configuration="qa"
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 16.1.4
Node: 16.18.0
Package Manager: npm 8.19.2
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 16.1.4
... animations, cdk, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core
... forms, language-service, localize, material
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1601.4
@angular-devkit/build-angular   16.1.4
@angular-devkit/core            16.1.4
@angular-devkit/schematics      16.1.4
@angular/flex-layout            15.0.0-beta.42
@schematics/angular             16.1.4
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.1.6
```


### Anything else?

This is a very large project that was started in Angular 2 5 years ago and now is up to angular 14 (upgrading over the years) and trying to get to 16. It literally took 3 days of package upgrades to get to this point from 14 to 16 so I would like to try to figure out what is going on. I can provide more information and or files if needed but would like any help I can get to try to figure out why this is no longer working when built v.s. running in development server.

The application is served up in IIS on a Windows server. Nothing has changed and this is the first time having this problem. 
Thanks in advance for your help.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular application will not run after upgrade to angular 16. " (#25533)

Issues.Title: semver@7.3.5 vulnerabilities in Angular 13.3.x
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

13.3.x versions still use semver v7.3.5 which is vulnerable to [Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS)](https://security.snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-JS-SEMVER-3247795)
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/30513671a2839714741eb7be5db24d3948841f12/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/package.json#L59

Also, please upgrade core-js to >=3.23.3

Yarn didn't raise anything but npm does warn about this
```
npm WARN deprecated core-js@3.20.3:
core-js@<3.23.3 is no longer maintained and not recommended for usage due to the number of issues. Because of the V8 engine whims, feature detection in old core-js versions could cause a slowdown up to 100x even if nothing is polyfilled. Some versions have web compatibility issues.
```

package.json

Issues.Title: bug(listbox): focus issue when moving back from another tab
Issues.Body: ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description Switching tabs can lead to a state where focused item is different from the item that will be toggled when pressing `Space`. That seems to be because `ActiveDescendantKeyManager` wrongly resets the `activeItemIndex` to 0, when tab is changed. ### Reproduction StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/8l74u6?file=src%2Fexample%2Fcdk-listbox-multiple-example.html,src%2Fexample%2Fcdk-listbox-multiple-example.ts 1. select "Chinese" and then "Italian". Active index is correctly 2. 2. move to another tab 3. move back to the stackblitz tab 4. Now "Italian" is still shown as the focused item, and is in fact focused (document.activeElement is the "Italian"'s LI item), But pressing Space will toggle the first item. As shown in the example, it seems the issue is rooted in ListKeyManager changing the activeItemIndex to 0, when focus is lost by moving to another. Here is how activeItemIndex is not in sync with the focused item, after moving back to stackblitz tab: ### Expected Behavior Pressing Space after moving back to the example's tab should toggle "Italian", which was and is still focused. ### Actual Behavior Pressing Space after moving back to the example's tab toggles "Chinese" which is not focused. ### Environment - Angular: 15,16 - CDK/Material: 16.1.5 - Browser(s): Chrome (and probably other browsers) - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(listbox): focus issue when moving back from another tab" (#27474)

Issues.Title: bug(MatRadioGroup): paging options prevents keyboard focus
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Using a `mat-paginator` to page the options in a `MatRadioGroup` prevents the radio group from receiving focus using the tab key on pages other than the first page.

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/q2wcmz

Steps to reproduce:
1. Click in the input box at the top to give it focus
2. Press tab; note that the radio group receives focus
3. Press tab again; note that this gives focus to the next-page button in the paginator
4. Press space or enter to change to the next page; note that the radio group options have changed
5. Press shift+tab; note that the paginator previous-page button receives focus
6. Press shift+tab again; note that the input box receives focus, skipping over the radio group
7. Press tab; note that the paginator receives focus, skipping over the radio group


### Expected Behavior

After changing pages, the radio group should still be able to receive focus using the keyboard.

### Actual Behavior

After changing pages, the radio group is unable to receive focus using the keyboard

### Environment

- Angular: 15.1.1
- CDK/Material: 15.1.1
- Browser(s): Chrome 114.0.5735.110, Firefox 115.0.2 (64-bit)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(MatRadioGroup): paging options prevents keyboard focus" (#27461)

Issues.Title: fix(material/radio): clear selected radio button from group
Issues.Body:
In  #18081 the radio group was changed so that deselected buttons receive `tabindex="-1"` when there's a selected button. The problem is that we weren't clearing the reference to the selected button so it gets removed, the deselected buttons become unfocusable using the keyboard.

These changes clear the selected radio button on destroy.

Fixes #27461.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(material/radio): clear selected radio button from group" (#27466)

Issues.Title: bug(MatFormFieldModule): Resize not working when using in standalone
Issues.Body:
### Description

I spent lots of hours trying to find why I'm unable to resize my `mat-form-fields` and then found out that it is only not working beacuse we are using standalone components instead of NgModule.


### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
I used the example from the official docs (v14, https://v14.material.angular.io/components/form-field/overview#form-field-theming) to reproduce this in Stackblitz:

1. This is a working example: https://stackblitz.com/edit/pghvre-upgcdz?file=package.json
2. This is the link with the same example, but as standalone component: https://stackblitz.com/edit/pghvre-sczu3y?file=src%2Fmain.ts


### Expected Behavior

No matter if I use `standalone: true` or an `NgModule` based setup the result should be the same. The padding that is applied to the form field should shrink like it does when using it with `NgModule`.


### Actual Behavior

In the standalone version, different classes are generated which don't render the correct resizing:
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/2816893/29696e84-00f6-4a5a-9c11-3697d143d718)

For comparison, this is what the element looks like if `NgModule` is used:
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/2816893/750c0e68-bced-4339-9459-cfecb414fbb2)

What I don't understand is why the "mdc" classes are applied on the one version and the "appereance" classes on the other one.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.1.4
- CDK/Material: 16.1.4
- Browser(s): Chrome and Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 11

#### Edit
I updated the working Stackblitz to v16 as well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(MatFormFieldModule): Resize not working when using in standalone" (#27452)

Issues.Title: fix(material/chips): wait for onStable when editing a chip
Issues.Body:
Address timing issue with MatChipRow. When a chip enters the editing state wait for ngZone's `onStable` event before accessing the ViewChild for the MatChipEditInput. Attempts to fix issue where editable chip goes blank when entering the editing state (#27462).

What seemed to be happening is that the view would render the MatChiEditInput when setting `_isEditing` to true, but sometimes the ViewChild would not be initialized in the component. Address this issue by adding additional wait using `_ngZone.onStable`.

Fix #27462.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/chips): wait for onStable when editing a chip" (#27464)

Issues.Title: build: update dependency build_bazel_rules_nodejs to v6
Issues.Body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [build_bazel_rules_nodejs](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs) | http_archive | major | `5.8.3` -> `v6.0.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>bazelbuild/rules_nodejs (build_bazel_rules_nodejs)</summary>

### [`v6.0.0`](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/releases/tag/v6.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/compare/5.8.3...v6.0.0)

#### Using Bzlmod with Bazel 6

1.  Enable with `common --enable_bzlmod` in `.bazelrc`.
2.  Add to your `MODULE.bazel` file:

```starlark
bazel_dep(name = "rules_nodejs", version = "6.0.0")
```

#### Using WORKSPACE

Paste this snippet into your  file:

```starlark
load("@​bazel_tools//tools/build_defs/repo:http.bzl", "http_archive")
http_archive(
    name = "rules_nodejs",
    sha256 = "a833b08fc846e27a73ac2b7062e4f48cace0e72a072c6c3fa756847dc44246dd",
    strip_prefix = "rules_nodejs-6.0.0",
    url = "https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/releases/download/v6.0.0/rules_nodejs-v6.0.0.tar.gz",
)
```

#### What's Changed

-   Update NodeJS Versions by [@​mattem](https://togithub.com/mattem) in [https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/pull/3622](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/pull/3622)
-   Update NodeJS Versions by [@​mattem](https://togithub.com/mattem) in [https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/pull/3628](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/pull/3628)
-   chore: update release instructions by [@​alexeagle](https://togithub.com/alexeagle) in [https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/pull/3632](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/pull/3632)

Issues.Title: feat(theme): add the ability to add (even partial) background and foreground to color object
Issues.Body:
feat(theme): add the ability to add (even partial) background and foreground to color object

While declaring the primary, accent and warn via the color object is easy and straight-forward, the configuration of foreground and background proves rather tedious. This commit adds the ability to declare foreground and background in the color object when defining a theme, even partially, meaning that missing values are taken from the default light or dark theme respectively.

Fixes #11390, #6244

Issues.Title: feat(MatDialog): Implement hide/show methods
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

This feature was previously discussed on #5162.

The proposed solution was to use the addPanelClass method to hide the dialog. But it doesn't work if you are using a backdrop. I built a [demo](https://stackblitz.com/edit/hide-md-dialog-with-backdrop?file=src%2Ftest%2Ftest.component.ts) to show the problem ([TestDialog01Component](https://stackblitz.com/edit/hide-md-dialog-with-backdrop?file=src%2Ftest-dialog-01%2Ftest-dialog-01.component.ts)).  There is no way to get the current overlay of the dialog to dispose of it manually  (See #15840).

I could find a workaround ([TestDialog02Component](https://stackblitz.com/edit/hide-md-dialog-with-backdrop?file=src%2Ftest-dialog-02%2Ftest-dialog-02.component.ts)) by not using the built-in backdrop and creating a custom overlay. But it feels too hacky.

The MdDIalog should have a built-in hide/show method or expose the overlayRef. 

If the team accepts it, I could implement it and send a PR.

### Use Case

I think in at least two use cases:

- An expensive operation to render the dialog.
- Using [Optimistic UI](https://uxplanet.org/optimistic-1000-34d9eefe4c05) to hide the modal as soon as the user clicks the button, but it needs to run some async operations that depend on each other, so you cannot destroy the modal until all the operations are complete (my use case).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(MatDialog): Implement hide/show methods" (#27448)

Issues.Title: feat(MatStepper): Ability to focus the current step header
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

I would like to be able to programmatically set focus to the current step header.

### Use Case

There are 2 use cases where I would like to be able to programmatically set focus to a step header:

1. When initially loading a page, I want to be able to give focus to the current step header.
2. When switching between steps programmatically using `MatStepper.next`, if anything has been done that caused the focus to shift outside of the stepper, the intended behavior of focusing the newly-selected header does not happen. I need to be able to move the focus back to the current step header.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(MatStepper): Ability to focus the current step header" (#27450)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(Guide): Define a typography level
Issues.Body:
### Documentation Feedback

The documentation states that I can customize the font size via:

```
@use '@angular/material' as mat;

$my-custom-level: mat.define-typography-level(
  $font-family: Roboto,
  $font-weight: 400,
  $font-size: 1rem,
  $line-height: 1,
  $letter-spacing: normal,
);
```

How can I actually make use of `$my-custom-level`? It seems that this part is missing in the documentation.

### Affected documentation page

https://material.angular.io/guide/typography#define-a-level
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "docs-bug(Guide): Define a typography level" (#27449)
